module: CSK-5 Module 5: Codes, Interpretation & Civil Litigation Practice

questions.question: When a civil-law lawyer in Indonesia first maps out a problem, what is their primary point of reference?

options.A: Claims that they look for published law firm alerts before consulting legislation.
options.B: Claims that they review recent Supreme Court cases because stare decisis is binding.
options.C: Claims that they start with the relevant Civil Code book because the code is the main source of law.
options.D: Claims that they begin with customary practice and only use the code if no custom exists.

A.explanation: Client alerts may help, but the authoritative source remains the legislation.

B.explanation: Case law is persuasive rather than binding; stare decisis does not control civil-law courts.

C.explanation: Civil-law systems such as Indonesia and Thailand are built around comprehensive codes, so practitioners start by reading the relevant Civil Code provisions.

D.explanation: Custom can influence interpretation, yet only after the coder provisions are consulted.

questions.question: How do Indonesian civil courts treat long lines of uniform decisions on the same point of law?

options.A: Claims that uniform precedents automatically bind all lower courts.
options.B: Claims that they are treated as foreign law and must be proved by experts.
options.C: Claims that the decisions are ignored because only statutes matter.
options.D: Claims that they acquire persuasive force under the constant-jurisprudence doctrine and guide later judges.

A.explanation: Civil-law courts are not bound by stare decisis; precedent is persuasive, not binding.

B.explanation: Domestic precedents do not need to be proved like foreign law.

C.explanation: Uniform case law is considered; it is not ignored outright.

D.explanation: When past rulings are consistent, courts treat the line as persuasive guidance under the constant-jurisprudence principle.

questions.question: What makes Civil Code Book 3 central to Indonesian commercial work?

options.A: Claims that it regulates contracts, including default rules for sales, hire and loans.
options.B: Claims that it codifies family and succession matters.
options.C: Claims that it only deals with criminal offences related to commerce.
options.D: Claims that it is the only book that has been repealed in its entirety.

A.explanation: Book 3 covers obligations and specific contracts, so it supplies the default civil-law rules for commercial dealings.

B.explanation: Family and succession issues are handled in Books 1 and 4.

C.explanation: Criminal offences sit outside the Civil Code and are governed by separate statutes.

D.explanation: Book 3 remains in force and is relied on daily by Indonesian lawyers.

questions.question: How do Indonesian legislators deal with outdated Dutch-language provisions in the Civil Code?

options.A: Claims that they simply ignore the code and leave the issue unresolved.
options.B: Claims that they translate the entire code into English each year.
options.C: Claims that they enact new statutes or implementing regulations that override or clarify the old provisions.
options.D: Claims that they amend the Dutch text directly in every case.

A.explanation: Lawmakers actively address gaps; they do not leave matters untouched.

C.explanation: Correct option is D; see explanation for why translation is key.

D.explanation: Revising the original Dutch text is difficult, so new legislation is preferred.
